prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We observe the redshifted CO(4-3) line and continuum emission simultaneously. We chose the correlator mode with a 1.875 GHz bandwidth in the frequency domain mode and use four spectral windows in four basebands to maximize the continuum sensitivity with the total bandwidth of 7.5 GHz.

The aim of this proposal is to detect the CO line in GRB hosts, and we do not need spatially resolve the hosts. We use the angular resolution of 1", which is enough to cover the hosts and to avoid the contamination from nearby sources. This can be achieved with a 12-m array configuration and we do not need the ACA.

The requested sensitivity is estimated by using a SFR-L(FIR) relation and a L(FIR)-L'CO relation. It is known that L(FIR) correlates well with L'CO for local and high-redshift star-forming galaxies (e.g., Solomon & Vanden Bout 2005). In particular, there is a tight correlation between L(FIR) and L'CO(3-2) (Iono et al. 2009) because CO(3-2) traces denser gas compared to CO(1-0). We estimate the expected CO luminosities by using the SFR-L_(FIR) relation of Kennicutt (1998) and a L(FIR)-L'CO(3-2) relation of L'CO(3-2)=0.93 x log(L(FIR))-1.50 (Iono et al. 2009). Since the proposed GRB hosts are actively star-forming galaxies, we adopt the CO line ratios of M82; CO(3-2)/CO(1-0)=0.93 and CO(4-3)/CO(1-0)=0.85 (Carilli & Walter, 2013). We assume a line width of 180 km/s, which is obtained for the GRB hosts observed in cycle 0 (Hatsukade et al. 2014) and also a median value for z~1 star-forming galaxies derived from CO observations (Tacconi et al. 2010). We request a sensitivity which is enough to detect the CO line with SN >= 5 with a 50 km/s velocity resolution. The SFR of the target is listed in the main text. The achieved continuum sensitivities with 7.5~GHz bandwidth are enough to detect the dust continuum expected from their SFRs.

We observe the redshifted CO(4-3) line and continuum emission simultaneously. We chose the correlator mode with a 1.875 GHz bandwidth in the frequency domain mode and use four spectral windows in four basebands to maximize the continuum sensitivity with the total bandwidth of 7.5 GHz.

Since the proposed GRB hosts are actively star-forming galaxies, we adopt the CO line ratios of M82; CO(3-2)/CO(1-0)=0.93 and CO(4-3)/CO(1-0)=0.85 (Carilli & Walter, 2013). We assume a line width of 180 km/s, which is obtained for the GRB hosts observed in cycle 0 (Hatsukade et al. 2014) and also a median value for z~1 star-forming galaxies derived from CO observations (Tacconi et al. 2010). We request a sensitivity which is enough to detect the CO line with SN >= 5 with a 50 km/s velocity resolution. The SFR of the target is listed in the main text. The achieved continuum sensitivities with 7.5~GHz bandwidth are enough to detect the dust continuum expected from their SFRs.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Long-duration gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) are thought to be associated with the explosions of massive stars and are accordingly expected to reside in star-forming regions with molecular gas. There is ongoing debate as to whether GRBs occur in normal star-forming galaxies or under particular circumstances. Multi-wavelength observations of GRB host galaxies have been conducted, however, there is only a limited number of CO observations. We propose CO and dust continuum observations of 12 GRB hosts. This will be the first CO survey of GRB hosts and provide the largest sample with CO observations. Immediate objectives are (i) We derive molecular gas mass and star-formation efficiency, and compare them with other star-forming galaxies. (ii) We derive gas consumption timescale to see if the timescale is shorter than that of local star-forming galaxies as suggested by previous observations. (iii) We derive obscured star formation to understand whether GRBs trace star-formation rate or not. This project will double the sample with CO observations, or increase the sample with CO detections by a factor of five if we detect CO, which will significantly improve our understanding of GRB hosts.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Science, The University of Tokyo
Faculty of Applied Sciences, Delft University of Technology
ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
Institute of Astronomy, University of Tokyo
ELT (Extremely Large Telescope) Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
